elements.content: A large number of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have exhibited increasingly wide utilization in the field of chromatographic separation owing to their intrinsic fascinating properties. However, the previous studies on supported MOF coating-based chromatographic separation focused only on the synthesis and chromatographic performance of a certain kind of supported MOF coatings as stationary phases using the multiple-step, complicated, and time-consuming modification methods, which severely impeded the widespread application of MOFs in separation science. Herein, a high-efficiency and versatile methodology toward diverse supported MOF coating-based stationary phases to achieve high-efficiency chromatographic separation was first reported based on the immobilized cysteine (Cys)-triggered in situ growth (ICISG) strategy. As a proof-of-concept demonstration, four types of MOF crystals consisting of different ligands and metal ions (Zn2+, Cu2+, Fe3+, and Zr4+) were conveniently and firmly grown on a Cys-modified capillary using the ICISG strategy and employed as the functional stationary phase for electrochromatographic separation. A broad variety of neutral, acidic, and basic compounds were all separated in a highly efficient manner on the developed four MOF-coated columns. The maximum theoretical plate number for Cys-MIL-100­(Fe)@capillary was close to 1.0 × 105 plates/m, and the intraday, interday, and column-to-column repeatabilities of retention times for the four MOF-modified columns were all less than 5.25%. More interestingly, the diversified separation performance of the developed MOF-coated columns indicated that the preparation strategy and the skeletal structure of the MOF coating-based stationary phases have a significant influence on the electrochromatographic separation performance and column capacity. Benefiting from the strong universality and high applicability of the developed ICISG strategy, the present study provides an effective route to facilitate the design and fabrication of novel functional MOF-based chromatographic stationary phases.

elements.content: As a novel organic–inorganic composite porous crystalline material, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have aroused wide interest due to their excellent properties such as high porosity, large specific surface area, and adsorption affinities. Benefiting from the above fascinating characteristics, MOFs have shown great application prospects in adsorption, sensing, catalysis, separation, and other aspects. In particular, MOFs are eminently suitable for the fabrication of various functionalized chromatography stationary phases with large specific surface areas because of their excellent porosity and modifiable functionalities. Until now, multifarious MOFs have been developed as a porous stationary phase for chromatographic separation such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), capillary electrochromatography (CEC), and gas chromatography.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
As a novel organic–inorganic
composite porous crystalline
material, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have aroused wide
interest due to their excellent properties such as high porosity,
large specific surface area, and adsorption affinities. Benefiting from the above fascinating characteristics, MOFs have
shown great application prospects in adsorption, sensing, catalysis, separation, and other aspects. In particular, MOFs are eminently suitable for the fabrication of
various functionalized chromatography stationary phases with large
specific surface areas because of their excellent porosity and modifiable
functionalities. Until now, multifarious MOFs
have been developed as a porous stationary phase for chromatographic
separation such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), capillary electrochromatography (CEC), and gas chromatography.

elements.content: In recent years, much attention has been paid to the fabrication of supported MOF coatings as stationary phases for chromatographic separation, which could effectively address the issues of directly packed MOF-based stationary phases such as high backpressure and low separation performance. However, because of the intrinsic poor heterogeneous nucleation capability of MOF crystals on support surfaces, there are still many limitations in the previously reported methodologies for fabricating MOF-coated chromatographic stationary phases. More specifically, the previous research studies on supported MOF coating-based chromatographic separation focused only on the synthesis of a certain kind of supported MOF coatings as stationary phases and their separation performance. Furthermore, almost all of the existing preparative methods for supported MOF coating-based stationary phases such as postsynthetic modification, liquid-phase epitaxy, and layer-by-layer self-assembly in situ growth generally require multiple preparation steps or treatment cycles and sophisticated and time-consuming operation conditions. Consequently, the poor universality and low applicability of the preparation methodologies of MOF-coated stationary phases severely impede the widespread application of MOFs in separation science. Therefore, a highly efficient and versatile strategy to prepare diverse MOF coatings on support surfaces (e.g., spherical silica and fused silica capillary) as the stationary phases for chromatographic separation is urgently desirable but has not yet been reported to date.

elements.content: CEC, combining the advantages of capillary electrophoresis (CE) and HPLC, is an evolving and powerful chromatographic separation method. One of the key issues affecting the development of CEC is the column technique, whose critical component is the stationary phases. In this context, MOFs with high porosity and diverse functionalities are particularly well suited for preparing novel functionalized CEC stationary phases with a large specific surface area. Until now, some types of MOF coatings have been utilized for CEC separation and they exhibited excellent separation ability for different analytes. Nevertheless, the previously reported methodologies for fabricating MOF-coated stationary phases such as postsynthetic modification and in situ growth also suffered from the issues of poor universality, low applicability, and inferior separation ability, severely hindering the further exploitation and application of MOFs in CEC.

CEC, combining the advantages of capillary
electrophoresis (CE)
and HPLC, is an evolving and powerful chromatographic separation method. One of the key issues affecting the development of CEC is the column
technique, whose critical component is the stationary phases. In this context, MOFs with high porosity and
diverse functionalities are particularly well suited for preparing
novel functionalized CEC stationary phases with a large specific surface
area. Until now, some types of MOF coatings
have been utilized for CEC separation and they exhibited excellent
separation ability for different analytes. Nevertheless, the previously reported methodologies
for fabricating MOF-coated stationary phases such as postsynthetic
modification and in situ growth also suffered from the issues of poor
universality, low applicability, and inferior separation ability, severely hindering the further exploitation and application
of MOFs in CEC.

elements.content: Herein, we first reported a high-efficiency and versatile methodology toward diverse supported MOF coating-based stationary phases to achieve high-efficiency electrochromatographic separation. The synthetic strategy of MOF-coated stationary phases was inspired by the significantly accelerated formation of prenucleation clusters and MOF crystals induced by cysteine (Cys) and could be summarized as immobilized Cys-triggered in situ growth (ICISG) of MOFs. First, Cys was simply premodified on the inner surface of a fused silica capillary through silane coupling and Schiff base reactions, which acted as a strong trigger for the rapid growth of MOF crystals inside the capillary. Second, the spontaneous formation of the prenucleation clusters and further in situ rapid growth of various MOF crystals on the capillary inner wall were easily achieved in a one-step process because the immobilized Cys could effectively accumulate diverse metal cations because of the strong coordination interaction of Cys. Third, the ICISG strategy can effectively combine the merits of the excellent interfacial binding ability of the silane coupling agent, the outstanding metal ion coordination, and induced nucleation capability of cysteine. Accordingly, the ICISG strategy has strong universality and high applicability for fabricating MOF-coated chromatographic stationary phases. For a proof-of-concept demonstration, four types of MOF crystals composed of different metal ions and ligands, that is, ZIF-8, UiO-66, MIL-100­(Fe), and HKUST-1, were firmly grown on the Cys-modified capillary by a facile and rapid one-step process and employed as the electrochromatographic stationary phase for open tubular CEC (OT-CEC) separation of a broad variety of neutral, acidic, and basic compounds. Compared with the previously reported synthetic strategies for MOF-coated chromatographic stationary phases, the developed ICISG method possessed broader universality, stronger applicability, and higher separation efficiency. Therefore, the present study not only contributes to expanding the application potential of MOFs in CEC but also will pave a new avenue for designing and fabricating novel functional MOF-based chromatographic stationary phases.

elements.content: All the CE separations were conducted using an Agilent 7100 3D CE system (Waldbronn, Germany). The pH values of the buffer solutions were adjusted using a digital pH meter (FiveEasy Plus FE28, Mettler Toledo, Shanghai, China). Attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra were recorded using a Nicolet iS10 spectrometer (Nicolet, USA). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded using an SU-8020 instrument (Hitachi, Japan). The measurement of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) spectra was conducted using an Inca X-act system (Oxford, Britain). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were obtained from Dimension Icon (Bruker, Germany). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) from 2θ = 5 to 50° with a 0.02° increment. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were investigated by nitrogen adsorption on a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics, USA). The leaching of Zn2+ from the ZIF-8 coating was tested using an Agilent 730 ICP-OES system (Agilent Technologies, USA).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section
Apparatus and Characterization
All the CE separations
were conducted using an Agilent 7100 3D CE system (Waldbronn, Germany).
The pH values of the buffer solutions were adjusted using a digital
pH meter (FiveEasy Plus FE28, Mettler Toledo, Shanghai, China). Attenuated
total reflection Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra were
recorded using a Nicolet iS10 spectrometer (Nicolet, USA). Scanning
electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded using an SU-8020 instrument
(Hitachi, Japan). The measurement of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS) spectra was conducted using an Inca X-act system (Oxford, Britain).
Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were obtained from Dimension
Icon (Bruker, Germany). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded
using a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) from 2θ
= 5 to 50° with a 0.02° increment. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller
(BET) surface areas were investigated by nitrogen adsorption on a
Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics, USA). The leaching of
Zn2+ from the ZIF-8 coating was tested using an Agilent
730 ICP-OES system (Agilent Technologies, USA).

elements.content: The whole preparation process of the MOF-modified columns is schematically shown in , and the capillary needs the amino acid-premodified treatment before the subsequent modification of MOFs. First, the uncoated fused silica capillaries (48.5 × 40 cm, 50 μm i.d. × 375 μm o.d.) were pretreated according to our previous literature study. The obtained capillary was injected with an ethanol solution of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) (10%, v/v) for 60 min. Subsequently, the prepared capillary was rinsed with absolute ethanol for 5 min to remove the residue and dried with nitrogen. After this, the APTES-bonded capillary was successively injected with an aqueous solution of glutaraldehyde (2%, v/v, pH 11) and Cys or alanine (Ala) solution (2 mg/mL) for 60 min, respectively. Finally, the amino acid-modified capillary was flushed with ultrapure water for 10 min and dried with nitrogen. All operations were carried out at room temperature.

Preparation
of the Amino Acid-Modified Capillary Columns
The whole preparation
process of the MOF-modified columns is schematically
shown in ,
and the capillary needs the amino acid-premodified treatment before
the subsequent modification of MOFs. First, the uncoated fused silica
capillaries (48.5 × 40 cm, 50 μm i.d. × 375 μm
o.d.) were pretreated according to our previous literature study. The obtained capillary was injected with an
ethanol solution of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) (10%, v/v)
for 60 min. Subsequently, the prepared capillary was rinsed with absolute
ethanol for 5 min to remove the residue and dried with nitrogen. After
this, the APTES-bonded capillary was successively injected with an
aqueous solution of glutaraldehyde (2%, v/v, pH 11) and Cys or alanine
(Ala) solution (2 mg/mL) for 60 min, respectively. Finally, the amino
acid-modified capillary was flushed with ultrapure water for 10 min
and dried with nitrogen. All operations were carried out at room temperature.

elements.content: Preparation of MOF-coated columns using the ICISG strategy.

1

Preparation
of MOF-coated columns using the ICISG strategy.

elements.content: The growth of ZIF-8 crystals on the Cys-modified capillary involves only one step. Briefly, a fresh methanol solution containing 20 mM zinc acetate and 80 mM 2-methylimidazole was injected into the Cys-modified column and allowed to stand for 2 h to form ZIF-8 crystals on the capillary at room temperature. After being flushed with methanol for a few minutes, the ZIF-8-modified capillary (Cys-ZIF-8@capillary) was obtained. As a comparison, the in situ growth of ZIF-8 inside an unmodified capillary (ZIF-8@capillary) and an Ala-modified capillary (Ala-ZIF-8@capillary) as well as on a Cys-modified quartz plate (Cys-ZIF-8@plate), an unmodified quartz plate (ZIF-8@plate), and an Ala-modified quartz plate (Ala-ZIF-8@plate) was also conducted via a similar process as stated above. Furthermore, the ICISG strategy was also utilized for fabricating UiO-66, HKUST-1, and MIL-100­(Fe)-coated columns and quartz plates using similar methods. More details are provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
In Situ Growth of MOF Crystals inside the Amino Acid-Modified
Capillary Columns
The growth of ZIF-8 crystals on the Cys-modified
capillary involves only one step. Briefly, a fresh methanol solution
containing 20 mM zinc acetate and 80 mM 2-methylimidazole was injected
into the Cys-modified column and allowed to stand for 2 h to form
ZIF-8 crystals on the capillary at room temperature. After being flushed
with methanol for a few minutes, the ZIF-8-modified capillary (Cys-ZIF-8@capillary)
was obtained. As a comparison, the in situ growth of ZIF-8 inside
an unmodified capillary (ZIF-8@capillary) and an Ala-modified capillary
(Ala-ZIF-8@capillary) as well as on a Cys-modified quartz plate (Cys-ZIF-8@plate),
an unmodified quartz plate (ZIF-8@plate), and an Ala-modified quartz
plate (Ala-ZIF-8@plate) was also conducted via a similar process as
stated above. Furthermore, the ICISG strategy was also utilized for
fabricating UiO-66, HKUST-1, and MIL-100­(Fe)-coated columns and quartz
plates using similar methods. More details are provided in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The surfaces of quartz plates (chemically equivalent to a fused silica capillary) after modified by APTES or amino acids were characterized by ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. As shown in Figure S1, all the modified plates exhibited two new absorption peaks located at around 2920 and 2850 cm–1 compared with the bare quartz plate, which could be ascribed to the stretching vibration of C–H. The APTES-modified plate presented two characteristic absorption peaks at about 3300 and 3290 cm–1, which were related to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of amine groups, respectively. The other peaks at 1560 and 1482 cm–1 could be assigned to the deformation modes of amine groups. After modified with Cys or Ala, the characteristic absorption peaks of amine groups disappeared and new absorption peaks located at around 1571, 1615, and 1408 cm–1 were assigned to CN groups derived from a Schiff base condensation reaction between amine groups and aldehyde groups, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of carboxyl groups, respectively. Additionally, the absorption band at 2551 cm–1 of the Cys-modified plate was related to the −SH stretching vibration of Cys. Therefore, the characterization results of ATR-FTIR spectra indicated that Cys and Ala were successfully grafted on the APTES-modified quartz substrates. Furthermore, an EDS analysis was conducted to investigate the areal density and distribution of Cys on the capillary inner surface. As shown in Figure S2, the elements C, N, O, and S were uniformly distributed in the inner wall of the Cys-modified capillary, indicating that Cys was evenly grafted on the capillary inner surface.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
Characterization
The surfaces of quartz plates (chemically
equivalent to a fused silica capillary) after modified by APTES or
amino acids were characterized by ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. As shown
in Figure S1, all the modified plates exhibited
two new absorption peaks located at around 2920 and 2850 cm–1 compared with the bare quartz plate, which could be ascribed to
the stretching vibration of C–H. The APTES-modified plate presented two characteristic absorption
peaks at about 3300 and 3290 cm–1, which were related
to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of amine groups,
respectively. The other peaks at 1560
and 1482 cm–1 could be assigned to the deformation
modes of amine groups. After modified
with Cys or Ala, the characteristic absorption peaks of amine groups
disappeared and new absorption peaks located at around 1571, 1615,
and 1408 cm–1 were assigned to CN groups
derived from a Schiff base condensation reaction between amine groups
and aldehyde groups, the asymmetric and
symmetric stretching of carboxyl groups, respectively. Additionally, the absorption band at 2551 cm–1 of the Cys-modified plate was related to the −SH stretching
vibration of Cys. Therefore, the characterization
results of ATR-FTIR spectra indicated that Cys and Ala were successfully
grafted on the APTES-modified quartz substrates. Furthermore, an EDS
analysis was conducted to investigate the areal density and distribution
of Cys on the capillary inner surface. As shown in Figure S2, the elements C, N, O, and S were uniformly distributed
in the inner wall of the Cys-modified capillary, indicating that Cys
was evenly grafted on the capillary inner surface.

elements.content: The morphologies of the fabricated MOF-coated columns were characterized by SEM. ZIF-8, one of the most studied MOF materials with good chemical and thermal stability, was chosen as an example and was investigated first. As shown in A–D, the inner wall of the bare capillary was fairly smooth, and the smoothness of the inner surface of ZIF-8@capillary was only slightly changed, indicating that it was difficult to directly grow ZIF-8 crystals on the unmodified column. After the capillary inner wall was premodified with Cys, it became very rough with many visible nanocrystals (G,H), confirming the successful in situ growth and immobilization of ZIF-8 crystals inside the capillary. By contrast, after the capillary inner surface was premodified with Ala, whose structure was similar to Cys except that the sulfydryl group was replaced by a methyl group, the roughness and the amounts of nanocrystals deposited on the Ala-ZIF-8@capillary significantly decreased compared with Cys-ZIF-8@capillary (E,F). On the other hand, it should be noted that APTES might also induce the growth of MOF crystals on the surface. For comparison, the in situ growth of ZIF-8 inside the APTES-modified capillary (APTES-ZIF-8@capillary) was also conducted using a similar process as stated above. As shown in Figure S4A,B, only few MOF crystals were grown on the APTES-ZIF-8@capillary, indicating that APTES had the weakest ability to induce the in situ growth of ZIF-8 crystals compared with Cys-ZIF-8@capillary and Ala-ZIF-8@capillary. The observed inferior coating effect obtained by the APTES layer was reasonable because the reaction conditions of the previously reported APTES-assisted strategy using the long-lasting solvothermal reaction under a high temperature were much more severe and time-consuming than those of the presented ICISG-assisted ZIF-8 coating process, which was rapidly completed within 2 h under room temperature.

elements.content: In order to quantitatively compare the area load of MOFs on the surfaces modified with different amino acids, some other characterizations of ZIF-8 coatings grown on the Cys- and Ala-modified quartz plates were performed. The AFM images of Cys-ZIF-8@plate and Ala-ZIF-8@plate shown in Figure S6 showed that Cys-ZIF-8@plate owned a more uniform and denser ZIF-8 coating than Ala-ZIF-8@plate. In addition, an EDS analysis (Figure S3) was conducted to further compare their area load. The element mapping images clearly indicated that Cys-ZIF-8@plate possessed much stronger element signals than Ala-ZIF-8@plate, corresponding to the greater amount of ZIF-8 crystals grown on the Cys-modified plate (Table S1), which was measured by comparing the quality differences before and after the growth of the coating. All these results clearly demonstrated that the strong coordination interaction between the immobilized Cys and Zn2+, which benefited from the coexistence of both sulfhydryl and carboxyl groups in Cys and has been demonstrated by Ouyang’s group via the xylenol orange-based colorimetric method, played a critical role in the highly efficient heterogeneous nucleation and growth of ZIF-8 crystals on the capillary inner surface. Additionally, the dense growth of UiO-66, MIL-100­(Fe), and HKUST-1 nanocrystals inside the capillaries premodified with Cys was also clearly observed (Figure S5), further demonstrating the broad universality and strong applicability of the ICISG strategy for fabricating diverse supported MOF coating-based electrochromatographic stationary phases.

elements.content: The crystal structures of the MOF-modified quartz plate whose preparation processes were the same as those of Cys-assisted MOF-coated columns were further investigated by XRD. The diffraction peaks of Cys-ZIF-8@plate were consistent with those of the simulated ZIF-8 (A), demonstrating the successful growth of the ZIF-8 crystal. In contrast, only very weak diffraction signals related to ZIF-8 were observed on Ala-ZIF-8@plate and no diffraction signals of ZIF-8 could be observed on ZIF-8@plate. Furthermore, the strong diffraction peaks of other three MOFs grown on the Cys-modified quartz plates were also clearly observed and consistent with their respective simulated signals (Figure S7B–D). The results of XRD were in accordance with the observed results of SEM and further confirmed the key role of immobilized Cys for the highly efficient heterogeneous nucleation and in situ growth of the four MOF crystals.

highly efficient heterogeneous nucleation and in situ growth of the
four MOF crystals.

elements.content: Next, the electro-osmotic flow (EOF) of the as-prepared capillaries was further assessed using dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as the EOF marker. As shown in B, among all the evaluated capillaries, the bare column had the maximum EOF values and the lowest was for the APTES-modified column, which might be due to the positively charged amine groups existing in the APTES layer as well as the partial masking of silanol groups. After ZIF-8 nanocrystals were grown inside the capillaries assisted by Ala or Cys, the EOF mobilities of the ZIF-8-coated columns were between those of the bare column and the APTES-immobilized column across the whole range of pH, which might be because of the masking of the APTES sublayer by ZIF-8 crystals. In addition, the other three Cys-assisted MOF-coated columns also exhibited similar phenomena of EOF inhibition in different degrees (Figure S7A), which further confirmed that the four kinds of MOF crystals were successfully grown on the capillary inner surface.

elements.content: The stability of the MOF coatings on the substrate surface in the running buffer is an important precondition for their potential applications. Cys-ZIF-8@plate was taken as an example to study the stability of the MOF layer in buffer solutions by evaluating the leaching amount of Zn2+ at different times in the phosphate buffer. As shown in Table S2, although the leaching amount of Zn2+ in the phosphate buffer gradually increased along with the time extension, the measured leaching amount of Zn2+ was very low (nanogram level), and the leakage ratio of Zn2+ from the ZIF-8 coating was less than 1% even after 24 h. Moreover, the SEM images of Cys-ZIF-8@capillary after CE separation (Figure S4C,D) demonstrated that the ZIF-8 coating inside the capillary did not change significantly even after long-time CE operation. Therefore, these results showed that the ZIF-8 layer possessed good stability in running buffer.
elements.clean_text:
Stability of the ZIF-8 Coating in the Running Buffer
The
stability of the MOF coatings on the substrate surface in the
running buffer is an important precondition for their potential applications.
Cys-ZIF-8@plate was taken as an example to study the stability of
the MOF layer in buffer solutions by evaluating the leaching amount
of Zn2+ at different times in the phosphate buffer. As
shown in Table S2, although the leaching
amount of Zn2+ in the phosphate buffer gradually increased
along with the time extension, the measured leaching amount of Zn2+ was very low (nanogram level), and the leakage ratio of
Zn2+ from the ZIF-8 coating was less than 1% even after
24 h. Moreover, the SEM images of Cys-ZIF-8@capillary after CE separation
(Figure S4C,D) demonstrated that the ZIF-8
coating inside the capillary did not change significantly even after
long-time CE operation. Therefore, these results showed that the ZIF-8
layer possessed good stability in running buffer.

elements.content: Figure S9A shows the effects of acetonitrile content of 3–15% on the separation performance of Cys-ZIF-8@capillary for neutral compounds. The baseline separation of five substituted benzenes, which were used as the model neutral analytes, could be easily achieved when the content of acetonitrile in the phosphate buffer ranged from 3 to 9%. These results indicated that the ZIF-8 layer had a strong separating capacity for the neutral analytes even though the size of the pore window of ZIF-8 (3.4 Å) was smaller than those of substituted benzenes (5.0–7.0 Å). This interesting phenomenon was reasonable because the previously reported studies indicated that the framework structure of ZIF-8 had strong flexibility and the gate opening effect allowed the larger aromatic molecules to enter the pore network. Moreover, as the acetonitrile content continued to increase, their retention times gradually increased but their resolution continuously decreased. When the acetonitrile content exceeded 12%, the peaks even overlapped partially. The phenomena could be ascribed to the facts that the growing elution ability of the organic solvent would weaken the interaction between substituted benzenes and the ZIF-8-based stationary phase and the continuously decreased EOF mobilities (Figure S8A) would reduce the migration rates of the neutral analytes. Furthermore, as shown in Figure S9B, the logarithmic values of the retention factors (log k) of the analytes were further calculated. There was a good linear correlation between the acetonitrile content and log k, with the correlation coefficient (R 2) not lower than 0.94. Thus, the possible separation mechanism of substituted benzenes on Cys-ZIF-8@capillary mainly depends on the hydrophobic interaction between the hydrophobic micropores of ZIF-8 nanocrystals and the hydrophobic analytes.

elements.content: The pH value and the buffer concentration significantly affect the EOF, thus leading to the change in the retention time and separation performance of the analytes. With the increase in the buffer concentration from 10 to 100 mM or the decrease in the pH value from 9.0 to 5.0, the migration time of analytes continuously increased (Figure S10), which could be attributed to the gradually decreased EOF (B and Figure S8B). Interestingly, baseline separation for the five substituted benzenes was easily obtained within all the investigated buffer concentration and pH ranges, demonstrating the superior separation performance of the Cys-ZIF-8@capillary. More especially, when the pH value was 7.0 and the buffer concentration was 70 mM, the maximal theoretical plate number of substituted benzenes (up to 7.5 × 104 plates/m) was achieved ().

elements.content: The developed Cys-ZIF-8@capillary was further utilized for separation of other neutral analytes (i.e., chlorobenzenes and halogenated benzenes), basic analytes (i.e., diamine isomers), and acidic analytes (i.e., diphenol isomers). As shown in and Figure S11, all the neutral and charged compounds could be separated in a highly efficient manner on Cys-ZIF-8@capillary under their respective optimal electrophoresis conditions. By contrast, no sign of separation of the three types of neutral analytes and only partial separation of the two types of charged compounds were observed on the bare column and ZIF-8@capillary under the same electrophoresis conditions, indicating that no effective coating was formed on the inner wall of the ZIF-8@capillary. Additionally, only partial separation of the neutral analytes and diphenol isomers could be obtained on Ala-ZIF-8@capillary and APTES-ZIF-8@capillary (Figure S13) because of the inferior ability of Ala and APTES to induce in situ growth of ZIF-8 crystals compared with Cys and thus fewer ZIF-8 nanocrystals could be immobilized on the APTES-modified (Figure S4A,B) and Ala-modified capillaries (E,F and A). Similarly, the previously reported ZIF-8-coated capillary, which was prepared using the polydopamine-assisted immobilization strategy, could only partially separate the similar neutral compounds with a relatively low column efficiency. Therefore, these results further demonstrated the strong practicability of the ICISG strategy for fabricating high-quality MOF-modified capillaries for high-performance electrochromatographic separation.
elements.clean_text:
Separation of Other Neutral
and Charged Compounds on Cys-ZIF-8@Capillary
The developed
Cys-ZIF-8@capillary was further utilized for separation
of other neutral analytes (i.e., chlorobenzenes and halogenated benzenes),
basic analytes (i.e., diamine isomers), and acidic analytes (i.e.,
diphenol isomers). As shown in  and Figure S11, all the
neutral and charged compounds could be separated in a highly efficient
manner on Cys-ZIF-8@capillary under their respective optimal electrophoresis
conditions. By contrast, no sign of separation of the three types
of neutral analytes and only partial separation of the two types of
charged compounds were observed on the bare column and ZIF-8@capillary
under the same electrophoresis conditions, indicating that no effective
coating was formed on the inner wall of the ZIF-8@capillary. Additionally,
only partial separation of the neutral analytes and diphenol isomers
could be obtained on Ala-ZIF-8@capillary and APTES-ZIF-8@capillary
(Figure S13) because of the inferior ability
of Ala and APTES to induce in situ growth of ZIF-8 crystals compared
with Cys and thus fewer ZIF-8 nanocrystals could be immobilized on
the APTES-modified (Figure S4A,B) and Ala-modified
capillaries (E,F and A). Similarly, the previously reported
ZIF-8-coated capillary, which was prepared using the polydopamine-assisted
immobilization strategy, could only partially
separate the similar neutral compounds with a relatively low column
efficiency. Therefore, these results further demonstrated the strong
practicability of the ICISG strategy for fabricating high-quality
MOF-modified capillaries for high-performance electrochromatographic
separation.

elements.content: In order to further prove the universality and applicability of the ICISG strategy, three other MOF-modified columns, including Cys-UiO-66@capillary, Cys-HKUST-1@capillary, and Cys-MIL-100­(Fe)@capillary, were prepared using this strategy for CEC separation. As shown in and Figure S12, baseline separation of the five types of analytes with high column efficiency, including neutral, acidic, and alkaline compounds, could be easily achieved on all the three MOF-modified columns under their respective optimal conditions. Interestingly, in our previous study, the UiO-66-modified capillary fabricated using the postmodified strategy showed relatively low column efficiency for the separation of two types of aromatic compounds. The distinct difference in the separation effects of the two methods indicated that the preparation method of the MOF coating inside the capillary has a significant impact on the coating quality and electrochromatographic separation performance.
elements.clean_text:
Separation Performance and Loading Capacities of Four MOF-Modified
Columns
In order to further prove the universality and applicability
of the ICISG strategy, three other MOF-modified columns, including
Cys-UiO-66@capillary, Cys-HKUST-1@capillary, and Cys-MIL-100­(Fe)@capillary,
were prepared using this strategy for CEC separation. As shown in  and Figure S12, baseline separation of the five types
of analytes with high column efficiency, including neutral, acidic,
and alkaline compounds, could be easily achieved on all the three
MOF-modified columns under their respective optimal conditions. Interestingly,
in our previous study, the UiO-66-modified
capillary fabricated using the postmodified strategy showed relatively
low column efficiency for the separation of two types of aromatic
compounds. The distinct difference in the separation effects of the
two methods indicated that the preparation method of the MOF coating
inside the capillary has a significant impact on the coating quality
and electrochromatographic separation performance.

elements.content: On the other hand, the previously reported MIL-100­(Fe)- and HKUST-1-modified columns, which were prepared using the multiple-step and time-consuming layer-by-layer self-assembly or liquid-phase epitaxy methods, also showed a relatively weak separation capability compared with those prepared using the ICISG strategy (Table S3). For instance, the previously reported column efficiency for the separation of substituted benzenes using an MIL-100­(Fe)-coated column was relatively low, and the baseline separation of halogenated benzenes could not be achieved on the previously reported HKUST-1-coated column. By contrast, the ICISG method not only greatly simplified the in situ growth processes of MOF coatings but also significantly improved the separation performance and application potential of MOF-coated columns.

the ICISG method not only greatly simplified the in situ growth processes
of MOF coatings but also significantly improved the separation performance
and application potential of MOF-coated columns.

elements.content: Furthermore, the separation performance and column capacities of the developed four MOF-modified columns also have differences in various degrees (Figure S14, , and Table S4). As shown in Figure S14, it was found that the loading capacities of the four MOF-modified columns ranged from around 1.2 to 3.6 mg/mL by determining the peak widths at half height (W 1/2) of the model analyte methylbenzene. All of them were well above than that of the ZIF-90-coated capillary (0.7 mg/mL) prepared by postsynthetic modification. In particular, the Cys-MIL-100­(Fe)@capillary exhibited the highest separation performance and column capacity among them. To better elucidate these phenomena, the BET surface areas of the four MOF-coated capillaries were, respectively, measured and are listed in Table S5. Their column capacities normalized by the BET surface area of Cys-ZIF-8@capillary followed an order of MIL-100­(Fe) > ZIF-8 > UiO-66 > HKUST-1, which was in the reverse order of their cavity diameters. Therefore, the excellent separation performance and column capacity of Cys-MIL-100­(Fe)@capillary were mainly because of the high porosity and unique pore structure of MIL-100­(Fe). More specifically, compared with the other three MOF-modified columns, the larger pore size of MIL-100­(Fe), which contains mesoporous cages (25–29 Å) and microporous windows (5.5–8.6 Å) simultaneously, contributes to reducing the mass transfer resistance of various analytes entering and leaving its internal cavities, thus greatly improving the electrochromatographic separation performance. In contrast, even though Cys-HKUST-1@capillary had the highest BET surface area, its normalized column capacity was the lowest among all the four capillaries, which might be due to the smallest cavity diameter of HKUST-1.

elements.content: Collectively, the diversified and outstanding separation performance of the developed four MOF-modified columns not only demonstrated the strong universality and excellent applicability of the ICISG strategy but also showed the great influence of the preparation strategy and the skeleton structure of MOF coating-based stationary phases on the electrochromatographic separation performance. First, the preparation strategy has an important influence on the crystalline quality and immobilized quantity of MOF coatings on the substrate surface. Second, the MOFs with high porosity and a large BET surface area contribute to improving the specific surface area of the MOF-based stationary phases and increasing the amounts of interaction sites. Third, the functional features and the pore sizes of the MOF skeletons have a marked impact on the separation performance and mechanism of MOF coating-based stationary phases. When the guest molecules are smaller than the sizes of the window and cavity of MOFs, the MOFs with larger pore sizes and stronger interaction sites are more likely to show a superior chromatographic separation performance. If the sizes of guest molecules are equivalent to or larger than the pore sizes of MOFs, the sieving effects might become very important for the chromatographic separation.
elements.clean_text:

strong universality and excellent applicability of the ICISG strategy
but also showed the great influence of the preparation strategy and
the skeleton structure of MOF coating-based stationary phases on the
electrochromatographic separation performance. First, the preparation
strategy has an important influence on the crystalline quality and
immobilized quantity of MOF coatings on the substrate surface. Second,
the MOFs with high porosity and a large BET surface area contribute
to improving the specific surface area of the MOF-based stationary
phases and increasing the amounts of interaction sites. Third, the
functional features and the pore sizes of the MOF skeletons have a
marked impact on the separation performance and mechanism of MOF coating-based
stationary phases. When the guest molecules are smaller than the sizes
of the window and cavity of MOFs, the MOFs with larger pore sizes
and stronger interaction sites are more likely to show a superior
chromatographic separation performance. If the sizes of guest molecules
are equivalent to or larger than the pore sizes of MOFs, the sieving
effects might become very important for the chromatographic separation.

elements.content: The repeatability and stability of the prepared four MOF-modified columns are the essential preconditions for their possible practical application. First, their repeatability was explored according to the relative standard deviations (RSDs) of the retention times of substituted benzenes ( and Tables S6–S8). The intraday, interday, and column-to-column RSDs for the four MOF-modified columns were all less than 5.25%, confirming their good repeatability. In addition, after 200 consecutive runs on the four MOF-modified columns, their good separation performance for substituted benzenes was maintained without significant variation of migration times and peak shapes (Figure S15). These results indicated that the MOF-modified columns prepared using the ICISG strategy had good repeatability and stability.

Repeatability and Stability
The repeatability and stability
of the prepared four MOF-modified columns are the essential preconditions
for their possible practical application. First, their repeatability
was explored according to the relative standard deviations (RSDs)
of the retention times of substituted benzenes ( and Tables S6–S8). The intraday, interday, and column-to-column RSDs for the four
MOF-modified columns were all less than 5.25%, confirming their good
repeatability. In addition, after 200 consecutive runs on the four
MOF-modified columns, their good separation performance for substituted
benzenes was maintained without significant variation of migration
times and peak shapes (Figure S15). These
results indicated that the MOF-modified columns prepared using the
ICISG strategy had good repeatability and stability.

elements.content: In summary, a highly efficient and versatile ICISG strategy was reported to fabricate diverse supported MOF coating-based stationary phases for high-performance electrochromatographic separation. Four types of MOF crystals, including ZIF-8, HKUST-1, UiO-66, and MIL-100­(Fe), were in situ grown on the inner surface of a Cys-modified capillary using the facile ICISG strategy and further utilized for the high-efficiency and robust separation of a wide range of analytes. Interestingly, the seldom reported room-temperature synthesis of MIL-100­(Fe) could be easily achieved using the ICISG strategy and the corresponding stationary phase exhibited excellent separation performance. Compared with the previously reported synthetic strategies for supported MOF coating-based chromatographic stationary phases, the ICISG method not only greatly simplified the in situ growth processes of MOF coatings but also possessed broader universality and stronger applicability. More importantly, the diversified separation performance of the developed four MOF-coated columns indicated that the preparation strategy and the skeleton structure of the MOF coating-based stationary phases have a significant influence on the separation performance and column capacity of MOF-based CEC. The proposed new methodology for preparing diverse MOF coating-derived stationary phases not only is conducive to expanding the application potential of MOF-based CEC but also provides a new way to design and fabricate novel functionalized MOF-based chromatographic stationary phases.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In summary, a highly
efficient and versatile ICISG strategy was
reported to fabricate diverse supported MOF coating-based stationary
phases for high-performance electrochromatographic separation. Four
types of MOF crystals, including ZIF-8, HKUST-1, UiO-66, and MIL-100­(Fe),
were in situ grown on the inner surface of a Cys-modified capillary
using the facile ICISG strategy and further utilized for the high-efficiency
and robust separation of a wide range of analytes. Interestingly,
the seldom reported room-temperature synthesis of MIL-100­(Fe) could
be easily achieved using the ICISG strategy and the corresponding
stationary phase exhibited excellent separation performance. Compared
with the previously reported synthetic strategies for supported MOF
coating-based chromatographic stationary phases, the ICISG method
not only greatly simplified the in situ growth processes of MOF coatings
but also possessed broader universality and stronger applicability.
More importantly, the diversified separation performance of the developed
four MOF-coated columns indicated that the preparation strategy and
the skeleton structure of the MOF coating-based stationary phases
have a significant influence on the separation performance and column
capacity of MOF-based CEC. The proposed new methodology for preparing
diverse MOF coating-derived stationary phases not only is conducive
to expanding the application potential of MOF-based CEC but also provides
a new way to design and fabricate novel functionalized MOF-based chromatographic
stationary phases.
